item.title: Pat add a quote by Harper Lee
item.description: "Atticus told me to delete the adjectives and I'd have the facts." -- Harper Lee

item.title: Pat add a quote by Harper Lee
item.description: "I wanted you to see what real courage is, instead of getting the idea that courage is a man with a gun in his hand. It's when you know you're licked before you begin, but you begin anyway and see it through no matter what. - Atticus Finch" -- Harper Lee

item.title: Pat add a quote by Harper Lee
item.description: "People generally see what they look for, and hear what they listen for." -- Harper Lee

item.title: Pat add a quote by Harper Lee
item.description: "You never really understand a person until you consider things from his point of view... Until you climb inside of his skin and walk around in it." -- Harper Lee

item.title: Pat add a quote by Haruki Murakami
item.description: "If you only read the books that everyone else is reading, you can only think what everyone else is thinking." -- Haruki Murakami

item.title: Pat add a quote by Philip Sington
item.description: "To rehearse imaginary conversations on paper is called literature. To do so out loud is called madness." -- Philip Sington

item.title: Pat add a quote by Philip Sington
item.description: "I wanted her body and soul, but body first." -- Philip Sington

item.title: Pat add a quote by Philip Sington
item.description: "One thing I knew about the novelist’s task: when in doubt, write; when empty, write; when afraid, write. Nothing is more impenetrable than the blank page. The blank page is the void, the absence of sense and feeling, the white light of literary death." -- Philip Sington

item.title: Pat add a quote by Philip Sington
item.description: "Desire is an appetite, quickly sated. Longing is a wound, an opening in the heart or the spirit. Whatever the cause, whatever the duration, it almost always leaves a scar." -- Philip Sington

item.title: Pat add a quote by Philip Sington
item.description: "The railway was part scalpel, part movie camera, slicing the city open, parading its inner workings at fifty frames per second. It was on the S-Bahn that she felt least abandoned, as if the act of travelling turned back the clock, and brought her nearer to the future she had lost." -- Philip Sington

item.title: Pat add a quote by Philip Sington
item.description: "And then they would watch her closely as the dark, coagulated masses took form before her eyes, became flesh and bone, became gradually human. For all their show of reluctance, she had a sense that they enjoyed introducing her to these horrors, as seducers took pleasure in the corruption of innocence." -- Philip Sington

item.title: Pat add a quote by Philip Sington
item.description: "One of the joys of being in love is that it clarifies your priorities. Complication arises from not knowing what you want." -- Philip Sington

item.title: Pat add a quote by Philip Sington
item.description: "All writers are insecure, the male ones especially. It's well known. Why else would they spend so much time on make-believe? They're only happy in their imaginary worlds, because that's where they're in charge - where they're God. Did you know that Hemingway's mother dressed him as a girl until he was six years old?" I was not offended by Claudia's glib psychological theory. Like many glib psychological theories, it struck me as fundamentally correct." -- Philip Sington

item.title: Pat add a quote by Philip Sington
item.description: "For the writer under Actually Existing Socialism describing sex is a simple matter: he simply does not do it (the describing, I mean, not the sex)." -- Philip Sington

item.title: Pat add a quote by Phillip Sington
item.description: "But then, he calls many things mad that he does not care for. Perhaps that is easier than accepting them." -- Phillip Sington

item.title: Pat add a quote by Erich Maria Remarque
item.description: "I am young, I am twenty years old; yet I know nothing of life but despair, death, fear, and fatuous superficiality cast over an abyss of sorrow. I see how peoples are set against one another, and in silence, unknowingly, foolishly, obediently, innocently slay one another." -- Erich Maria Remarque

item.title: Pat add a quote by Erich Maria Remarque
item.description: "It is very queer that the unhappiness of the world is so often brought on by small men." -- Erich Maria Remarque

item.title: Pat add a quote by Erich Maria Remarque
item.description: "We are not youth any longer. We don’t want to take the world by storm. We are fleeing. We fly from ourselves. From our life. We were eighteen and had begun to love life and the world; and we had to shoot it to pieces." -- Erich Maria Remarque

item.title: Pat add a quote by Erich Maria Remarque
item.description: "We are forlorn like children, and experienced like old men, we are crude and sorrowful and superficial—I believe we are lost." -- Erich Maria Remarque

item.title: Pat add a quote by Kurt Vonnegut
item.description: "Seems like the only kind of job an American can get these days is committing suicide in some way." -- Kurt Vonnegut

item.title: Pat add a quote by Kurt Vonnegut
item.description: "It shook up Trout to realize that even he could bring evil into the world — in the form of bad ideas." -- Kurt Vonnegut

item.title: Pat add a quote by Kurt Vonnegut
item.description:
"I'm not a drug salesman. I'm a writer."
"What makes you think a writer isn't a drug salesman?" -- Kurt Vonnegut

item.title: Pat add a quote by Kurt Vonnegut
item.description: "Round and round we spin, with feet of lead and wings of tin." -- Kurt Vonnegut

item.title: Pat add a quote by Philip Sington
item.description: "We drank our coffee the Russian way. That is to say we had vodka before it and vodka afterwards." -- Philip Sington

item.title: Pat add a quote by Philip Sington
item.description: "Old Prague was a story-book city caked in grime: ancient, soot-blackened. History lived in every detail: in the deerstalker rooftops and the blue-sparking trams. He wandered the streets in disbelief, photographing everything, images from Kafka crowding into his head. With the turn of every corner it came back to him: the special frisson you get behind enemy lines." -- Philip Sington

item.title: Pat add a quote by Philip Sington
item.description: "He reached into the grate, picked out a couple of scraps, smoothed them out, leaning close to the flickering light. He was curious to see what it was Zoia had decided to destroy." -- Philip Sington

item.title: Pat add a quote by Philip Sington
item.description: "That was the dream of Montparnasse: to live for the moments of the greatest intensity, to find in them a truthful inspiration, and to hell with all the rest." -- Philip Sington
